Hypenotic The Jekyll Butler

Tapping into Fiesta Farms’ Quirky Authenticity

09 Sep 2010

We’ve had a bit too much fun lately creating video content for Fiesta Farms. First we helped the staff of Fiesta fete the new Mayor of Fiesta Farms on Foursquare, and then we made a Double Rainbow spoof video to promote Grow for the Stop veggies’ arrival.

The strategy for Fiesta Farms is based on the idea that Food Matters for different people for a number of different reasons–but that for Fiesta Farms’ shoppers it’s always about more than filling their fridge and their bellies. But that doesn’t mean we have to be earnest all the time. In fact, we’ll leave that job to Whole Foods.

Fiesta Farms is Toronto’s largest independent grocery store. That gives them the freedom to buy from farms and entrepreneurs other, bigger guys, can’t. But it also gives them them the ability to be a little off beat. If you’ve been to the store, you know that it has a little quirk deep in its bones. It’s an unpolished space. Its employees feel like real people. Its owner, Joe Virgona, is an iracible guy who has a heart of gold.  And that’s what makes Fiesta Farms so easy to love.

We have a lot of fun playing up Fiesta’s charmingly quirky side. Too much fun perhaps. But eating your veggies doesn’t have to be boring.

Also, special thanks to the super-duper talented Aaron at Tarazat Studios who leant us a hand with editing the Mayor video.
